STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 11, 2024
Lynn Sepolen
St. Vincent Catholic Charities- Child Welfare
2800 W. Willow St.
Lansing, MI, 48917-1833
Re: License #: CB330201019
Dear Ms. Sepolen:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on 3/7/24.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB330201019
Licensee Group Organization: St Vincent Catholic Charities
Licensee Designee: Joseph Garcia
Chief Administrator: Lynn Sepolen
Name of Agency: St. Vincent Catholic Charities- Child Welfare
Agency Address: 2800 W. Willow St.
Lansing, MI 48917-1833
Agency Telephone #: (517) 323-4734
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not
later than 6 months after the staff member
assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation must be
conducted every 12 months.
Three of three employee files did not have performance evaluations completed
within the past year.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(2) For an emergency placement, if any of the
information specified in subrule (1)(a) to (h) of this rule is
not available at the time of placement, then the agency
shall provide information to the foster parent within 7
calendar days of the placement.
One of three foster care files did not have placement information documented as
required.
2

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
Two of three foster care files held treatment plans that did not have signatures by
the foster parent or youth to indicate the plan was provided to or reviewed with
them.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Three of three adoption files held family assessments that were not completed
within the required timeframe.
FOM 722-06B Pg 5 Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
• Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Two of three foster care files did not have an FTM completed within 30 days prior to
the USP due date.
One of three foster care files did not have an FTM completed within the required
timeframe for placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED: 4/3/2023 RENEWAL, CAP approved
4/17/23
3

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Borrowed Beds- Per the CWLM User Guide, Borrowed Bed agreements and
accompanying documentation should be uploaded in the general documents
section of the provider record. When a Borrowed Bed agreement begins, the
loaning agency must assign a staff person from the borrowing agency as a
secondary worker.
• CPR/First Aid certification- Licensing rules require certification in CPR/First
Aid. Passing the online test is not adequate documentation.
• Family Team Meetings- Per FOM 722-06B (Page 10) If a parent/caregiver
declines to attend or participate in the pre-meeting discussion or FTM, the
meeting must proceed with other participants in attendance. If no other
participants are identified, the caseworker and supervisor must proceed with
a case conference to assess and plan for the child’s safety, permanency, and
well-being. The caseworker must make active efforts to engage the parent or
caregiver in the FTM process until case closure. Engagement efforts and a
parent’s denial of participation must be documented in the case service plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
A CAP, approved 4/17/23, was the result of the 4/3/23 renewal evaluation. During
the 2023 review the agency had violations regarding references in personnel files,
borrowed bed agency agreement, and family team meetings (FTM). The agency
reported successful implementation of the prior CAP. During the current review the
agency was found to show improvement in all areas of the CAP. However, a
repeat violation was determined regarding FTMs. A new CAP will be developed to
address this repeat violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) was reviewed and discussed on-site.
The CAA indicated strategies were implemented to improve compliance from the
4

2023 review. Strategies included increased timeframes to schedule FTMs,
calendar reminders, additional supervisory oversight, implementation of trackers,
and staff training. The CAA indicated the agency has improved in many areas.
However, they’ve found that parent contacts are sometimes challenging as the
parents are not always willing to engage with agency staff. The lack of willingness
to engage contributed to FTMs not being completed timely.
The CAA identified two disrupted placements for one youth this year. The
placement changes were due to caregiver request because of the youth’s
increased behavioral challenges. The agency increased worker and supervisor
contacts and support and held FTMs in order to preserve the placement.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff reported they really enjoy their jobs
and have excellent supervisors. Both staff stated they did not have any concerns
or suggestions for improvements within the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same office building as previous years.
The office has secure storage for confidential information. There is adequate
space for staff and clients to conduct business and hold visitation.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
_____________March 8, 2024_________________________
Heather A Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 11, 2024
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
5
